pros: There are none that come to mind
cons: Out of touch management Enables Medicare fraud Micromanaging out of control No structured training and orientation for hospice nurses; they are just released into the ‘wild’ with limited support Human Resources only has managements back and will enable management to disseminate repercussions for those who question processes and work flow Office and most nursing staff on verge of retirement and are simply burned out which makes for a very negative culture

pros: The orientation process was generous with training over the first month and then contact with preceptor and trainer after that for questions and tune ups. Certain managers are good hearted and do their best to solve problems. There are almost always plenty of patients. We were paid through the lockdown, no matter what our patient load was. There is some good teamwork between staff members, which largely depends on what you as an individual do to build that.
cons: There is a culture of management shifting blame so you have to get certain things on email and save it. In the Boston side of the company, there are unresolved labor relations issues which have gone on for over 4 years which feeds into a lack of agility in responding to challenges. No performance evaluations or raises during this time. At times, management turns a blind eye to repeated reports of urgent need for a change.

job_title: Patient Care Representative in Worcester, MA
pros: They may be trying to save the business
cons: The company is losing money fast.  The benefits are far from competitive, the pay is terrible, and there is a lot of pressure put upon every employee.  The management is horrible, and the clinicians are treated far better than the office staff.  Clinicians think they can visit patients without a true need and get angry at the staff when they tell them that they need to discharge patients because there is no medical need to visit.  The management team doesn't listen to the employees and permit bullying to occur to some staff members without true discipline.  Hard working employees that are loyal seem to be less important at times than the ones that can either crank out as much work as possible or that need to have a hand held most days.   The staff always walks on eggshells as nobody knows if they will have a job, and sometimes they don't make you feel validated.  Other times, you are.    There is no room for growth and unless you have a title like RN BSN, you are nobody.

pros: Paycheck didn’t bounce...However not getting paid for overtime and scared to report in fear of job loss
cons: The COO is fiscally irresponsible.   His coworker CF is totally unfit for her job.  The exc mgmt all have company cars.  High salaries and bonuses meanwhile paying rent on a vacant building in Boston after displacing a full Office staff  and field clinicians   now laying off 35 staff from valuable clerks to desperately needed nurses some who started less than 2 months ago proving this to be another poorly thought out process ‘in an effort to save money and provide great care...bla bla bla ‘.   The staff aren’t allowed any real input as the upper mgmt already have their minds made up.  Mgmt not paying staff hours worked   Staff afraid to speak up in fear of job loss but they did have an ice cream social last summer!!

review_title: Patient oriented is not a reality!
pros: Enjoy working with coworkers who are dedicated to the profession
cons: Unrealistic productivity with additional paperwork that needs to be performed by therapist at home and he/she not reimbursed for those hours.work/life balance is poor.  Large company  at this time  covering  from the cape  to middle of Massachusetts on both New Hampshire and Connecticut borders .  This makes  employee  satisfaction  not  prioritized . Money oriented at this time even though CEO is reporting patient oriented. Company is unable to accommodate therapist if they have their own medical issues. Company has been pushing long-standing employees out and sudden layoffs. Company cannot be trusted

review_title: Poorly organized, not a positive work environment
pros: Great nurses, people who care and advocate for their patients.
cons: Terribly managed.  Moral is constantly low.  Not enough nurses or support from upper management.  Constant disorganization from staffing to IT.

review_title: Got out in time, VNA Care ruined VNA of Boston
pros: Co workers (peers, not  upper management) who strived to provide excellent patient care despite horrible working conditions.   Ability to provide care to patients in their home
cons:
VNA of Boston WAS  a wonderful company with a focus on providing excellent care to Boston home care patients.  VNA Care and management team(including newest CEO) eventually infiltrated and overran what was once a patient centered organization (VNA of Boston), with a new focus only on bottom line.  It became,  frankly embarrassing, to work here and I became concerned for my own reputation as a clinician by being associated with VNA Care.
Every week valuable caregivers leave this organization-upper management does not care but ultimately this continues to weaken this company.

pros: The nurses are excellent. They are very knowledgeable and support one another.  Nurses are patient advocates and will go above and beyond to assure the patients receive the highest level quality of care.  The atmosphere is relaxed a majority of the time. The nurses love what they do.
cons: Extremely unorganized at the middle management level.   Poor communication at the middle management level.  "The right hand doesn't know what the left hand is doing or communicating".  Communication breaks  throughout the company.  Middle and higher management are very dismissive of the nurses input and ideas to improve care.   Does not provide 25% free care as designated. The medical directors  interest in the company does not include the best interest of the patient, rather "her" best interest in being right is most important.   There is no continuing education for nurses offered by the company. Company provides $200 annually for "continuing education" on our own.   Makes many patient care related cutbacks, but will find money to renovate and redecorate new employee offices.   There is no room for personal growth as they want to keep the nurses at arms length at all times.  When on call, may be alone servicing an extremely large geographical area and are expected to see as many as 10 patient "visits" (on a busy day) which can include, pronouncements and admissions.  Computer time extends far beyond our shift, and at times cannot be paid for that extensive time.  Compensation is below average, no one can work 40hrs ( to save on benefits and ET), and there is minimal appreciation, as someone pointed out, the company does not recognize the clinical nurses during  nurses week, just the middle and higher management.

pros: independent in the field with someone to contact if needing help, usually see 6 patients a day.
cons: currently a lot of restructuring, hey just removed all team leaders  which is a bad ides. They don't have enough staff and you need to push patients often. documentation is over kill, not a lot of room to grow

pros: coworkers try to help one another
cons: new management, too many changes that are detrimental to the agency. Too much expected of employees, very unrealistic, what was once a nice place to work  has become very hostile, nobody looks forward to go to work.  no salary increase in 3-4 years, but upper management has company cars.

pros:
Great co-workers and team building field staff
Flexible schedule
cons:
Upper management way too heavy. Micromanagement. Compensation no where near the amount of work we do nd management has no clue the amount of time put into our jobs. 
Patients suffering and not getting time and visits they need due to upper management pushing numbers. Taking on way too many patients then staff can handle and current patients suffering by not getting seen. Poor communication office staff and no assistance with communication to patients on visits being pushed due to inappropriate not needed admission visits being done

job_title: Patient Account Representative in Southborough, MA
pros: Working Independently - that’s really it
cons:
After an influx of recent reviews, I too felt compelled to offer my own insight. Do not apply here. From the outside this company has a very strong reputation within the community for being a wonderful nonprofit that cares for patients in their homes and throughout end of life care. That is really where it stops. Throughout my experience here, I have to agree that a majority of the nurses and therapists that are employed here are truly wonderful with the patients and really do go above and beyond to help, regardless of what that means they themselves have to sacrifice. Now switch gears to what it’s like on the inside:

Cons: Under qualified management. Overpaid “supervisors” and favored employees that received their titles or pay raises simply because they share a last name or hometown with a higher up. Increasing workloads. Embarrassingly decreasing benefits including constantly rising employee contributions and a total discontinuation of employer 401k contributions. No pay raises across the board regardless of work ethic, length of dedication to the company or performance based merit. We receive the minimum legal amount of accrued sick time and when you want to use it you are denied or at the very least hassled and told your reasoning is unqualified or that you don’t actually have any time (which is more than often inaccurate and can be easily verified by the Payroll department). A typical day here feels like you are trying to ride a bike with square tires. Unproductive, inefficient and frustrating. We are told that we’re “lucky” to have “treats” that some other offices don’t have the “luxury” of receiving such as splenda, spoons and real milk in the refrigerator for coffee. Good luck finding basic supplies to even complete your task (if you do ignore all of these warning and take the job regardless of these reviews I suggest stockpiling your desk - which will probably be broken - with supplies as often as you can because more often than not, you can not find it when you need it). 

This company is marketed by HR as an appealing place to apply your skills. It’s not. The vision statement here at the VNA is “Transforming care to improve lives”. I’ll tell you what - you life will be transformed if you chose to come on board here but probably
not in the ways that you were hoping for. You’ll find yourself in one of two categories: invincible or dispensable. The favoritism here is disgusting and blatant and management and HR absolutely can not be trusted. 

Lastly, employees are sent a letter annually requesting they donate a portion of their paychecks or a donation in any amount back to the company. The same company that is no longer giving out raises or matching 401k or allowing you to use your own earned sick time. 

Pros: If you’re lucky enough to work here long enough to attend one of the “christmas parties” you could wind up with a new can of paint or shake weight in the yankee swap, at the very least you’ll get a cold plate if eggs and stale danish. Also, you can kill a few minutes every week watching the required weekly videos sent via email from the new CEO. The production quality takes me back to the happier days of high school morning announcements scrolling across the TV in homeroom.

pros: At least their paychecks cleared.

This organization can't get out of its own way, and patients suffer greatly as a result. 

The hospice organization is abominable. 

They first stumbled in a major way when they took over the home care and hospice business from UMass in Worcester in 2012. Since then, they've acquired another VNA, and continue to compound problems of their own making. 

I would not let this organization anywhere near a friend or family member.
